ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basically you complete up the majority of the grammar in the Latin language as you finish Shelmerdine. We spent the rest of the semester reading a speech by Cicero called Pro Marcello.
I learned more Latin grammar and developed the necessary skills to translate passages from Latin into English.
i learned how to effectively memorize and interpret latin
I strengthened my Latin reading skills and finished learning Latin grammar.
I felt like I was really beginning to get to grasp with active translation
I learned lots of grammar topics along with how to properly go about translating material.
This course introduced me to the thought processes necessary for translating classic Latin texts.
Learned the more advanced Latin grammar concepts and began to translate actual texts in class

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The structure of this course really made sure that you understood the new grammar topics before moving on since there were many quizzes. With the translation part of the semester, it might have been nice to have more sessions where we tried to translate in smaller groups before going over it as a class.
It was a rigorous course that was well structured, especially once moving into translation work
Its tough that it meets on fridays. I think like Spanish 110 there should be an asynchronous day.

Like in LATN 110, much time is spent learning grammar mechanics from the textbook; these essentials are difficult to grasp because the textbook does not make clear what elements are and are not important, and the course moves too quickly to fully digest one grammar skill before moving to the next.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are interested in Latin, it is a well-organized and impactful course. If you feel that you may be bored fulfilling your language requirement in an area that you won't speak, and the majority of the prose you read is about war and philosophy, then it may not be for you.
Yes, if you want to learn Latin this is a great course.
I would to those who enjoy languages and are interested in latin
Yes. Its a very interesting language, and Thomas was great.

Latin is a good language credit for those who are not good at the oral aspect of learning languages, and Latin 2's curriculum, albeit rather quick, is very fair and comprehensive. The class was repetitive at times, as are all languages, but the small nature of the class helps you get to know your classmates, and it is enjoyable. Overall, I would definitely recommend Latin to other students.
